author: Kendall Powell
description: Human cells transplanted into animal brains provide insights into development and disease but also raise ethical questions.
title: Audio long read: Hybrid brains – the ethics of transplanting human neurons into animals

author: Jacqueline M. Cole
description: The application of machine learning to big data, to make quantitative predictions about reaction outcomes, has been fraught with failure. This is because so many chemical-reaction data are not fit for purpose, but predictions would be less error-prone if synthetic chemists changed their reaction design and reporting practices.
title: The chemistry of errors

author: Robin M. Cywar
description: A grand challenge for bio-based plastics is the ability to cost-effectively manufacture high-performance polymers directly from renewable resources that are also recyclable-by-design. A one-step conversion of xylose to polyesters has been reported, combining a sustainable lifecycle with impressive materials performance.
title: Producing performance-advantaged bioplastics

author: Tim Hugo Taminiau
description: A new method enables precise control of spin qubits in diamond by selectively activating them with a laser beam, thus paving the way to the control of spin qubits in dense arrays for applications in quantum technology.
title: Quantum gates activated with laser precision

author: Cally J. E. Haynes
description: Supramolecular catalysis can emulate many features of enzymatic transformations. Now, a complex proton wire mechanism — enabling the dual activation of a nucleophile and an electrophile through reciprocal proton transfer — has been shown to operate during the Î²-glycosylation of sugars within a self-assembled capsule.
title: Hopping protons in supramolecular catalysis

author: Anton Nalitov
description: The hardest barrier in the way to topological control over light with magnetic fields is extremely weak magneto-optic coupling. Now, strong light-matter coupling in an optical cavity has been used to reach record energy splitting values for photonic spins in magnetic fields. This is a potential game changer for topological photonics.
title: Polaritons elevate magneto-optic effect

author: Jeff Tollefson
description: Biden administration instructs all US agencies to require immediate access to federally funded research after it is published, starting in 2026.
title: US government reveals big changes to open-access policy

author: Ruby Prosser Scully
description: But the benefit of vaccines in reducing Omicron transmission doesn’t last for long.
title: COVID vaccines slash risk of spreading Omicron — and so does prior infection

author: Caroline Seydel
description: As new technology enables researchers to find and characterize less-common post-translational modifications that drive gene expression and cellular metabolism, the movement to catalog the entire human proteome gains momentum
title: Diving deeper into the proteome

author: Caroline Ospelt
description: ETS1 regulates tissue-remodeling properties of specific fibroblast subtypes in the synovium, gut and cancer and thus emerges as a novel cross-tissue therapeutic target for modulation of pathogenic fibroblast activation.
title: A common activator of tissue-remodeling fibroblasts across tissues

author: Stephanie A. Roberts
description: Immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICIs) are effective for many cancers but can be limited by inflammatory toxicities. Little is known about how ICIs affect the reproductive system. New research in animal models with and without tumours demonstrates that ovarian reserves are depleted in mice treated with ICIs, which may influence fertility.
title: Checking ovarian reserves after checkpoint blockade

author: Ajay Pillarisetti
description: Anaemia remains an intransigent global health problem that increases the risk of morbidity and mortality for women and children, and nowhere more so than in India. Now, a study links particulate air pollution exposure with anaemia in women of reproductive age.
title: Particulates and anaemia in India

author: Paul Tsoukas
description: Multisystem inflammatory syndrome in children (MIS-C) and Kawasaki disease are both hyperinflammatory disorders associated with infectious diseases, but are they distinct syndromes or do they exist along a continuum? A comparison of the host immune response in these illnesses provides surprising new insights.
title: Kawasaki disease and MIS-C share a host immune response

author: Roland Nilsson
description: Mass spectrometry imaging holds promise for mapping the intricate organization of metabolism in complex tissues. Wang et al. combine this exciting technique with metabolic tracing ex vivo to uncover metabolic specialization and adaptation in the mouse kidney.
title: Zooming in on kidney metabolism

author: Emily Waltz
description: Low cortisol levels and herpes-virus reactivation are associated with prolonged COVID-19 symptoms, preliminary research suggests.
title: Could long COVID be linked to herpes viruses? Early data offer a hint

author: Sarah Wild
description: The research funder’s admission has been largely welcomed, but experts say many institutions need to do much more to implement anti-racism pledges.
title: Wellcome says it has perpetuated ‘systemic racism’ in science

author: Cassandra Willyard
description: Two research teams grew synthetic embryos using stem cells, long enough to see some organs develop.
title: Mouse embryos grown without eggs or sperm: why and what’s next?

author: Davide Castelvecchi
description: Interaction between glass spheres suspended in a vacuum might one day lead to advances in quantum computing.
title: ‘Levitating’ nanoparticles could push the limits of quantum entanglement

author: Flora Graham
description: NASA’s Artemis 1 Moon mission is a big step towards landing the first woman on the Moon. Plus, what a seven-million-year-old leg bone says about whether an ancient human relative could walk upright, and how to respond to a year of Taliban rule in Afghanistan.
title: Daily briefing: The most powerful rocket ever built is about to launch

author: Max Kozlov
description: Tecovirimat, a little-known antiviral, shows promise against monkeypox. But human data and supplies of the drug are limited.
title: Can a smallpox drug treat monkeypox? Here’s what scientists know

author: Yvaine Ye
description: Data show the country is facing a demographic crisis, with an ageing population and young couples having fewer children.
title: When will China’s population peak? It depends who you ask

author: Benjamin Thompson
description: Embedded ‘nanocages’ help water dissolve large amounts of gas, and potential evidence that hominins walked on two legs seven million years ago.
title: How to make water that’s full of holes

author: Daeyeon Won
description: Periodic nanostructures create brilliant colours, termed structural colouration, through light scattering and refraction. Now, using a simple and scalable method, stress- and strain-induced dynamic colour shifts are realized in stretchable polymers.
title: The colour of stress

author: Sebastian Diehl
description: Precise optical experiments reveal that quantum excitations in semiconductors share similarities with a host of growing interfaces. The parallels inspire a fresh approach to studying the dynamics of diverse systems in a controllable way.
title: A new phase for the universal growth of interfaces

author: Daniel E. Lieberman
description: A leg bone and two arm bones of a hominin from Chad suggest that, seven million years ago, around the time that the human and chimpanzee lineages split, early hominins were bipedal but were also able to climb trees.
title: Standing up for the earliest bipedal hominins

author: Lorenzo Galluzzi
description: The net effect of type I interferon (IFN-I) signaling on tumor control depends on various factors, including the potential engagement of adaptive anticancer immunity. New findings delineate a targetable epigenetic mechanism by which suboptimal IFN-I signaling promotes tumor progression in the context of cancer stem cell expansion and immunoevasion.
title: Immuno-epigenetic escape of cancer stem cells

author: Michele De Bastiani
description: Epitaxial heterostructures of multi-dimensional halide perovskites are demonstrated by ligand-assisted welding, providing a platform for realizing hybrid systems with unique combined properties.
title: Rising of halide perovskite epitaxial structures

author: Amy E. M. Beedle
description: By maximizing cell–substrate force transmission, cancer cells can migrate towards either stiffer or softer substrate regions.
title: In search of a softer environment

author: Margarida Costa Gomes
description: Porous solids have been dispersed in water to produce suspensions that can carry much more oxygen than blood can. Such ‘porous water’ opens the way to water-based formulations for biomedical use.
title: Suspended pores boost gas solubility in water

author: Frank Scheffold
description: Structuring surfaces coated with nanoparticles in the subwavelength range allows almost complete control over the optical appearance of an object.
title: Metasurfaces provide the extra bling

author: Smriti Mallapaty
description: The country has invested hundreds of millions of dollars into research on induced pluripotent stem cells to treat diseased organs.
title: Pioneering stem-cell trials in Japan report promising early results

author: Flora Graham
description: Debate over hypothesis that long COVID is linked to tiny, persistent clots that constrict blood flow to vital organs. Plus, ancient teeth reveal the origins of cold sore herpes virus, and we gaze at the most distant star ever observed.
title: Daily briefing: Do tiny blood clots cause long COVID?

author: Cassandra Willyard
description: Scientists debate evidence for a micro-clot hypothesis that has some people pursuing potentially risky treatments.
title: Could tiny blood clots cause long COVID’s puzzling symptoms?

author: Alexandra Witze
description: The most powerful rocket ever built will soon head for the Moon, carrying with it a trove of satellites and radiation experiments.
title: NASA’s Artemis Moon mission is set to launch: here’s the science on board

author: Yang Chai
description: Silicon-based dual-gate photodiodes with electrostatically controlled photocurrents can be used to create imaging systems that can compute incoming visual data.
title: Silicon photodiodes that multiply

author: Nadera J. Sweiss
description: Lack of understanding of the immunology of sarcoidosis has limited therapeutic progress. However, evidence from a small open-label trial suggests that treatment with the Janus kinase inhibitor tofacitinib can improve sarcoidosis symptoms, predominantly by inhibiting type 1 immunity.
title: Sarcoidosis: can tofacitinib slay the dragon?

author: Preston A. Humphries
description: The inhibitory checkpoint molecule CTLA-4 is essential for regulatory T cell function. A new study highlights the differential manner in which CTLA-4 binds CD80 and CD86, which determines its cellular fate and orchestrates immune tolerance regulation.
title: Two CTLA-4 ligands, separate pHates

author: Paul S. Mischel
description: Structural variants (SVs), such as copy-number alterations, rearrangements and aneuploidies, are common somatic changes in cancer genomes and rich sources of driver oncogenes, but reconstructing these from sequencing data is a challenge. Two new studies shed light on the diversity and importance of the SV landscape in cancer.
title: Form follows function in cancer genomes

author: Flora Graham
description: Jupiter flaunts faint rings, tiny moons and background galaxies in new Webb image. Plus, Anthony Fauci will leave his NIH role and how a couple of dozen British bunnies sparked Australia’s catastrophic rabbit invasion.
title: Daily briefing: Spectacular Jupiter image from James Webb Space Telescope

author: Freda Kreier
description: Teeth from long-dead people and animals are divulging the history of modern pathogens.
title: Ancient tooth DNA reveals how ‘cold sore’ herpes virus has evolved

author: Raveena Bhambra
description: Diseases of the central nervous system continue to catalyse dealmaking as companies search for new therapies to tackle some major unmet medical needs.
title: High-value dealmaking strengthens big pharma’s CNS ambitions

author: Kazuomi Kario
title: Digital Hypertension 2023: Concept, hypothesis, and new technology

author: John Meluso
description: A new Bayesian analysis of remote work data supports one of the oldest theories in social networks, with fresh implications for the future of work environments.
title: Model supports storied social network theory

author: John S. Ho
description: Delivering light therapy using a remotely controlled bioelectronic device implanted above the brain might complement current glioblastoma therapies, reducing cancer recurrence and improving survival.
title: Wireless nanomedicine for brain tumors

author: Veda Sheersh Boorla
description: Constraining metabolic models by enzyme capacities greatly improves genotype–phenotype predictions. author: Ahmed Ghouneimy
description: Assays leveraging the CRISPR-associated enzyme Cas13 and isothermal RNA amplification for the detection of viral RNA are being simplified for point-of-care use.

description: Polio and Guinea worm disease are top of the list for eradication, but some targets have been pushed back as campaigns hit myriad challenges.

title: Microbial regulation of cholesterol homeostasis

description: Greenland is rich in natural mineral resources and has been actively investigating the economic potential of expanded mineral extraction. However, public opinion calls for the assessment of the environmental and social impacts of mineral extraction.
title: Turning Greenland’s sand into gold

description: The presence of topologically protected edge states is usually determined by angular-resolved photoelectron spectroscopy, requiring clean surfaces and ultrahigh vacuum. Now, an all-optical technique, based on high-harmonic radiation, has been shown to detect topological phase transitions under ambient conditions.
title: Optically sensing topological phase transitions

author: Stefano Recanatesi
description: Determining how information flows throughout a network of interconnected components is a challenging task in many scientific domains. A framework is presented to deconstruct the flow of signals that are transmitted across any two areas (such as brain areas) and define how each area represents these signals.
title: Untangling network information flow

author: Guillaume Jaume
description: Weakly supervised deep-learning models for the analysis of whole-slide images from tumour biopsies perform better at prognostic tasks if the models incorporate context from the local microenvironment.
title: Integrating context for superior cancer prognosis

author: Sergey G. Menabde
description: Heterostructure of graphene and biaxial van der Waals crystal supports a species of plasmon-phonon-polaritons whose isofrequency dispersion contour can be manipulated while experiencing a topological transition.
title: Graphene unlocks dispersion of topological polaritons

author: Steve P. McGrath
description: The discovery of a natural variation in an ancient rice variety shows the way to reduce the harmful element cadmium in a key food without sacrificing yield and concentrations of other essential nutrients.
title: Keeping toxic cadmium out of the food chain

author: Jack Binysh
description: An active solid composed of confined robots is reported. Through elastic interactions, the robots sync up to create novel states of coherent motion.
title: Active solids sync up

author: Silvia Corvera
description: Adipose tissue plays a critical role in systemic metabolism. This work describes how perturbations in the adipocyte progenitor cell repertoire during the perinatal period exert long-lasting metabolic effects in adulthood.
title: Perinatal fat progenitors shape adult metabolism

author: Emma Stoye
description: A digital model suggests the colossal ancient shark could have eaten a whale in just a few bites. Plus: how bats inspire urban design and why the Tongan volcano eruption should be a wake-up call.
title: Daily briefing: Giant megalodon was longer than a bus

author: Giorgia Guglielmi
description: Disposing of these persistent substances often requires high pressures and temperatures.
title: How to destroy ‘forever chemicals’: cheap method breaks down PFAS

author: Guillaume Charras
description: The interior of the cell is organized with the help of dynamic structures that condense like droplets. A timing strategy ensures that cells maintain healthy function by avoiding uncontrolled growth of these condensates.
title: A biochemical timer phases condensates in and out in cells

author: Ramona Vogt
description: An analysis of the distribution of the elementary particles that make up the proton provides evidence that it contains a type of quark known as an intrinsic charm quark — verifying a proposal made four decades ago.
title: Evidence at last that the proton has intrinsic charm

author: Siddharth Ramachandran
description: Optical fibres can now directly generate a variety of Bessel beams thanks to custom-designed, intricate 3D-printed structures applied to their tips.
title: 3D-printing yields structured light

author: Katrin J. Meissner
description: Variations in ocean oxygen levels during Earth’s history have been linked to evolution and mass extinctions. Simulations now suggest that the configuration of the continents has a substantial impact on ocean oxygenation.
title: Plate tectonics controls ocean oxygen levels

author: Anne Marie Conlon
description: How even a small-scale nuclear conflict could cause a global famine, and why some parents are considering delaying their children’s second dose of the COVID vaccine.
title: Daily briefing: Nuclear war could spark global famine

author: McKenzie Prillaman
description: One ‘superspreader’ with Omicron shed 1,000 times as much viral RNA as those with Alpha or Delta.
title: How much virus does a person with COVID exhale? New research has answers

author: Ann Finkbeiner
description: After Russia’s invasion, politicians promised to boost military research funding — but policy specialists aren’t convinced that a rapid change lies ahead.
title: Will war in Ukraine mark a new era for European defence research?

author: Emma Stoye
description: The Inflation Reduction Act includes US$369 billion in climate investments over the next decade. Plus: measuring how much virus people with COVID exhale.
title: Daily briefing: New US law pledges billions to fight climate change

author: Jeffrey M. Perkel
description: Powerful ‘grammar’ allows geneticists to display their data in interactive and scalable illustrations.
title: A graphics toolkit for visualizing genome data

author: Elise S. Bisset
description: Mouse frailty can be measured with a frailty index by manually counting health deficits. Vivek Kumar and colleagues use machine learning to extract physical performance deficits from video data to create a ‘visual frailty index’. This automated technique may facilitate high-throughput research into new frailty interventions.
title: Machine learning to spot frailty in aging mice

description: Biden signs historic legislation to pour billions into fighting climate change as the global temperature continues to rise.
title: Scientists welcome ‘enormous’ US climate bill — but call for stronger action

description: Bristol Myers Squibb’s first-in-class TYK2 inhibitor and blockbuster contender deucravacitinib showcases the role for heavy hydrogen in novel drug discovery.

author: Shannon Hall
description: Increasing the interval between the first two mRNA-vaccine doses might boost children’s immunity, but it is a gamble as a new variant sweeps the globe.

description: The diode is a well-known component of semiconductor electronics, but equivalent behaviour in superconductors is rare. Now, two demonstrations of a superconducting diode effect show that this is possible, through different mechanisms.
title: Superconducting diode effects

description: Understanding what drives household-level decisions to keep cooking with polluting cookstoves and fuels must be grounded in theory for sustained change to occur. title: The cook behind the stove

description: Activation of the RAF protein is key to the RAS–MAPK signalling pathway, and involves the SMP protein complex. Structures for SMP shed light on the process, and suggest fresh targets for anticancer drug discovery.
title: Structural keys unlock RAS–MAPK cellular signalling pathway

description: In 1987, two independent groups cloned a gene that encoded the potassium-ion-channel protein Shaker, enabling functional and structural studies that have transformed ion-channel research.

title: Reinforcement learning supercharges redox flow batteries

description: The precise location of megamaser emission regions in galactic accretion disks has been challenging to pinpoint. Now with interferometric observations leveraging baselines larger than the Earth’s diameter, the missing information is getting closer and closer.
title: The super-resolved megamasers of NGC 4258

author: David Mayerich
description: Collateral arteries may act as natural bypasses that reduce hypoperfusion after a coronary blockage. 3D imaging of neonatal and adult mouse hearts, plus human fetal and diseased adult hearts, is now used to computationally predict flow within the heart, and understand the cardioprotective role of collateral arteries in vivo.
title: Computational insights on coronary artery function

author: McKenzie Prillaman
description: Heatwaves, droughts, floods and storms push up the number of cases, make diseases more severe and hamper people’s ability to cope.
title: Climate change is making hundreds of diseases much worse

author: Holly Else
description: Candidates face calls to prioritize research as the leadership contest heats up.
title: The UK is getting a new prime minister — what will it mean for science?

author: Clare Watson
description: Shifting winds and ocean currents are pushing warm waters into East Antarctica, contributing to ice loss, an analysis finds.
title: World’s largest ice sheet threatened by warm water surge

author: Sara Reardon
description: How researchers created complex tiling patterns with bioengineered bacteria
title: The geometry of life: when mathematics meets synthetic biology

author: Christof Weitenberg
description: Statistical correlations between particles play a central role in the study of complex quantum systems. A new study introduces microscopic detection of ultracold molecules and demonstrates the measurement of two-particle correlations.
title: Microscopes go molecular

author: Inga Steinbrenner
description: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is often well advanced before it is detected. Although polygenic scores may enable the early stratification of patients at risk of CKD, the transferability of polygenic scores for the prediction of CKD to populations of non-European ancestry was limited. A new cross-ancestry polygenic score for CKD overcomes these issues, demonstrating good performance across ancestries.
title: A polygenic score predicts CKD across ancestries

description: Elucidating the interactions between serum protein-bound nanoparticles and cell-surface receptors typically operates on a per protein–receptor interaction basis. Integration of omic approaches for testing thousands of interactions unbiasedly reveals important interactions that drive cellular uptake of nanoparticles.
title: Unbiased matchmaking

description: Computer simulations have revealed the topological nature of the liquid–liquid phase transition in colloidal water. This finding might lead to an experimental observation of this topological transition with colloids as building blocks.
title: Water untangled

description: Prolonged contact, especially with a person’s skin lesions, is emerging as the top transmission route.
title: How does monkeypox spread? What scientists know

author: Heidi Ledford
description: Difficult tasks can lead to build-up of a signalling molecule in the brain, triggering fatigue.
title: Why thinking hard makes us feel tired

title: COVID rebound is surprisingly common — even without Paxlovid

description: Immune cells called monocytes have long been implicated in the killing of invading bacteria. However, a closer look reveals a surprising role for them: monocytes partner with a hormone to improve skin healing after bacterial infection.
title: Immune cells use hunger hormones to aid healing

author: Peter Munro
description: Optical coherence tomography (OCT) is a three-dimensional optical imaging technique, frequently (but not exclusively) used for retinal imaging, that was first reported in the early 1990s. Since this time the technological development of OCT has been strongly influenced by its potential as a medical imaging technique. The first clinical prototype for use in ophthalmology was completed in 1994, paving the way for the first commercially available ophthalmic OCT system to be released to the market in 1996. Since then, OCT has become a mainstay of ophthalmology. OCT is also widely used in research, in an array of biomedical applications, and increasingly in industrial settings. Although there is still much activity in advancing OCT technology, there has been an increased emphasis in applying OCT to translational research. One direction of this research is in the development of quantitative and computational techniques to aid in the retrieval of clinically useful information from OCT images. This Collection brings together original research articles, which exploit realistic mathematical models of OCT image formation and machine learning approaches to obtain insight not otherwise available from raw OCT images. description: People with similar body odours are more likely to instantly get along as friends. Plus, China gets closer to its first mRNA vaccine and how to make spatial maps of gene activity — down to the cellular level.
title: Daily briefing: People who smell alike are more likely to ‘click’ as friends

author: Giorgia Guglielmi
description: Study looking at death rates early in the pandemic confirms that low-income nations have born the brunt of the global disaster.
title: COVID was twice as deadly in poorer countries

author: Michael Eisenstein
description: Computational and experimental methods are bringing researchers closer to their goal of revealing exactly where in a cell or tissue each gene is expressed.
title: How to make spatial maps of gene activity — down to the cellular level

author: Ankita Anirban
description: In the 20th century, Bell Labs was a renowned industrial research lab in the US, known as the birthplace of the transistor and for the discovery of cosmic microwave background radiation. It was also home to a 40-year minority outreach programme that went on to create a generation of Black scientists. What can initiatives today learn from the success of this fellowship?
title: Black scientists at Bell Labs

author: John Pickrell
description: A multitude of missions are heading to the Moon — will they be successful?
title: Audio long read: These six countries are about to go to the Moon

author: Todd R. Gingrich
description: Information thermodynamics offers a route to measure how effectively a light-driven molecular machine converts energy from absorbed photons into pumped motion.
title: Measuring how effectively light drives a molecular pump

author: Xiaofeng Wu
description: A diagnostic fragment ion in tandem mass spectrometry enables confident protein lactylation assignment and the discovery of broad lysine modification beyond histones.
title: Uncovering ubiquitous protein lactylation

author: Francesc Villarroya
description: Hepatic inflammation is a major co-morbidity in obesity. New work shows that activated brown adipose tissue releases maresin-2, a lipid molecule derived from docosahexaenoic acid, which targets the liver and actively protects against obesity-induced hepatic inflammation.
title: Brown fat resolves hepatic inflammation in obesity

author: E. Lisa F. Schipper
description: Years of research on adaptation to climate change shows that many efforts are counterproductively increasing vulnerability, rather than reducing it — known as ‘maladaptation’. Now a study suggests ways forward by identifying four structural challenges that need to be overcome in adaptation implementation.
title: Catching maladaptation before it happens

author: Nicholas P. R. Onuska
description: A compound made by plants used in traditional medicine has been prepared by chemical synthesis, providing enough for biological testing. The unexpected finding that it acts at opioid receptors raises prospects for drug discovery.
title: Synthesis reveals unexpected biological targets of a traditional medicine

author: Michael G. Christiansen
description: Fruit flies injected with magnetic nanoparticles and genetically modified to sensitize neural circuits to the rate of change in temperature have enabled subsecond behavioural responses to magnetic stimuli and multi-channel magnetic control.
title: Multi-channel control of fruit fly behaviour

author: Alexandre H. C. Anthis
description: An adhesive hydrogel patch made from off-the-shelf materials seals and aids the healing of gastrointestinal-tissue defects without the need for sutures, as shown with the repair of gastrointestinal leaks in live rats and pigs.
title: Sutureless gastrointestinal anastomoses

author: Alexander J. Baker
description: Quantifying historical trends in tropical cyclone activity has proved difficult, but a new reconstruction reveals a clear global decline over the past century, driven by an increasingly cyclone-hostile environment in the troposphere.
title: Global decline in frequency

author: Jan Petersen
description: Lymphocyte activation gene 3 (LAG3) is an important checkpoint inhibitor molecule of immunotherapeutic interest. New crystal structures of LAG3 provide important insight into its molecular architecture, laying the groundwork for future basic and applied investigations.
title: Overcoming the LAG3 phase problem

title: Passive radiant cooling without sacrificing the aesthetics of objects

title: Bacterial envelope built to a peptidoglycan tune

author: Sarah Janzen
description: The world’s poorest households, who often depend on agricultural incomes, are increasingly vulnerable to weather-induced shocks. A recent study shows how anti-poverty programmes can help to protect both consumption and income when exposed to shocks.
title: Anti-poverty programmes build resilience

author: Xin Zhou
description: A graph neural network-based tool is introduced to perform unsupervised cell clustering using spatially resolved transcriptomics data that can uncover cell identities, interactions, and spatial organization in tissues and organs.
title: Graphing cell relations in spatial transcriptomics

title: A trove of Asgard archaeal viruses

description: Researchers say a highly effective jab will help to avoid hospitals getting overwhelmed, but probably won’t end the country’s ‘zero COVID’ policy.
title: China’s first mRNA vaccine is close — will that solve its COVID woes?

author: Ewen Callaway
description: COVID-19 vaccines are due for an upgrade, scientists say, but emerging variants and fickle immune reactions mean it’s not clear what new jabs should look like.
title: Fast-evolving COVID variants complicate vaccine updates

author: Carrie Arnold
description: After decades of research and development, devices for detecting infectious agents in breath are finally maturing, with SARS-CoV-2 galvanizing progress. Carrie Arnold reports.
title: Diagnostics to take your breath away

author: Vivien Marx
description: Cameras are a crucial part of microscopes and are also built into many kinds of instruments. To make their output comparable takes standards.
title: The making of microscope camera standards

author: Vivien Marx
description: Imaging and microscopy technology advances in leaps and bounds. To address accumulated pain points, academics and companies are making headway on standards.
title: Imaging standards to ease reproducibility and the everyday

author: Noah Baker
description: We discuss the USA’s decision to authorize the Moderna and Pfizer COVID vaccines for children under five.
title: Coronapod: USA authorizes vaccines for youngest of kids

author: Janis Timoshenko
description: Rationalizing the difference in the catalytic properties within a group of materials is a challenging task. A method is now proposed that addresses this issue by predicting the activity and stability of platinum-based electrocatalysts from operando spectroscopic data.
title: Spectroscopy predicts catalyst functionality

author: Sanjana Srinivas
description: Supported subnanometre catalysts are atom efficient and possess unique properties, but their structure–activity relations are not well understood. Now it is possible to reveal their structure sensitivity by combining multimodal experiments and computations.
title: Tuning at the subnanometre scale

description: A newly discovered bacterium is up to a centimetre long. Plus, monkeypox insights from Africa and the public-health consequences of a US Supreme Court ruling on Roe v. Wade.

description: US cases of liver inflammation among children have remained flat, but UK cases seem to have risen, leading some to suggest a coronavirus contribution.
